message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about how objects appear in the night sky. When an object is far away and we try to observe it closely, it becomes hard to see because it puts distance between us. This is because the object occupies a smaller visual angle, making it less noticeable. Option (A) is incorrect because if the object gets closer, it would be easier to see, not harder. Options (B) and (C) are unrelated to the visibility of the object in the night sky.

This question requires an understanding of how distance affects visibility in the night sky. As an object moves farther away from a person, it becomes harder to see, especially in the dark. This is because the object's size in their visual field becomes smaller and it may blend in with the background of the night sky. Option (A) is incorrect because if the object gets closer to the person, it should become easier to see. Options (B) and (C) are unrelated to the visibility of the object in the night sky.

This question requires knowledge about how distance affects visibility. As the person in question observes the object in the night sky, if it starts to become hard to see, it suggests that the object is putting distance between them. This is because objects that are far away from us appear smaller and less visible compared to objects that are closer. Option (A) is incorrect because if the object gets closer, it would be more easily visible. Options (B) and (C) are unrelated to the visibility of the object and are therefore incorrect.
